DataElement.preferredName: Tumor Post Resection Pathologic Tumor Burden Value
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Numeric value of the sum of the maximum diameter of the new tumor as examined pathologically at the time of the surgical resection.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Tumor Post Resection Pathologic Tumor Burden
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias._Happening at a time subsequent to a reference time; later in time or order._The act of cutting out; the surgical removal of part or all of a structure or organ._A report that provides a description of the gross and microscopic examination of the specimen and is used to make a diagnosis and to determine treatment. It defines which structures and organs of the body are involved by the tumor, verifies the primary site of the cancer and describes the extent to which it has spread._Refers to the number of cancer cells, the size of a tumor, or the amount of cancer in the body. Also called tumor load.

Concepts.definition: A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Property.preferredName: Post Excision Pathology Report Tumor Burden
Property.preferredDefinition: Happening at a time subsequent to a reference time; later in time or order.:The act of cutting out; the surgical removal of part or all of a structure or organ. :The description of cells and tissues made by a pathologist based on microscopic evidence, and sometimes used to make a diagnosis of a disease.:Refers to the number of cancer cells, the size of a tumor, or the amount of cancer in the body. Also called tumor load.

Concepts.definition: Happening at a time subsequent to a reference time; later in time or order.
The surgical removal of a lesion, often as part of a biopsy and with healthy margins.

A report that provides a description of the gross and microscopic examination of the specimen and is used to make a diagnosis and to determine treatment. It defines which structures and organs of the body are involved by the tumor, verifies the primary site of the cancer and describes the extent to which it has spread.
Refers to the number of cancer cells, the size of a tumor, or the amount of cancer in the body.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: any measurements, including linear dimensions, volume, and weight, of a patient's tumor.

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: Released per approval by T.Lichtenberg. mc 7/24/12

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Refers to the number of cancer cells, the size of a tumor, or the amount of cancer in the body. Also called tumor load._A numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: indication of the presence and extent of disease.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Refers to the number of cancer cells, the size of a tumor, or the amount of cancer in the body. Also called tumor load.:A numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed.

Concepts.definition: Refers to the number of cancer cells, the size of a tumor, or the amount of cancer in the body.
A numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed.

ValueDomain.changeDescription: Curated for The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) by request of T. Lichtenberg 11/2010 sw

ReferenceDocuments.name: TCGA Form Instruction
ReferenceDocuments.description: This should include both well-differentiated and de-differentiated components.
